div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: A TREMENDOUS WORLD PROBLEM.
div.p: A tremendous world problem has begun, and is continuing, of which none can foresee the one. This problem is being played out in the United States, in Canada, in Australia, in New Zealand, and in South Africa. At first sight it seems merely a question of colour and of racial prejudice. But at bottom it is more than that - it is an economic question of the first order.

"Ultimately this may prove to be the most tremendous question upon which great masses of mankind have ever been divided," says the "Daily Telegraph," "but any attempt to settle it by arms, whatever the immediate issue, would mean sooner or later a hundred years' conflict ; and not for this generation only but | for many, the world's hopes for peace would be ennk deeper than Prosperó dropped his book."

"The real root of the trouble," thinks the "Times," "is not in any issue of general policy, but is to be sought in the friction arising from the economic competition in the same area of races differing wholly in habits and standards of living, and disinclined to amalgamate-a competition of whose difficulties we have already seen something within the British Empire, and with which we shall inevitably have to deal in the future. Of the difficulty created by this problem soine permanent solution based on equitable compromise will yet have to be found. Failing it, the trouble that is now creating such anxiety to all lovers of peace and civilisation will inevitably recur at a later period, and recur in a far more serious form."

"The standard of life among the Australian and American democracies," adds the "Telegraph", "would be utterly undermined by unrestricted Asiatic competition-nay, would be swamped if the vast floods of Chinese humanity, for instance, were to burst through the frail legislative dikes now holding them back from empty or half-peopled regions under white control; and the unrestricted ingress of labour from the Far East would be more insidiously and totally destructive of white welfare than war itself. In one word, this is not a color question; it is fundamentally an economic question. We trust our allies will take it at that, and will realise that the point of national honour has been accidentally caught op with the problem, but is not permanently involved in it. It would be as illogical to make war upon it as to make war against the McKinley tariff. Goods and men alike are discriminated against for economic reasons."

"Those who look forward to a conflict at some time or other caused by the determination of the Japanese to press, and the determination of the Anglo Saxon overseas, both in America and in Australia and New Zealand, to resist, the claim of the Japanese to enter and to help to develop territories bordering on the Pacific which the white man considers reserved for his special occupation, can, unfortunately, not be described as mere visionaries or dreamers," says the Spectator." "The hard, practical facts of the case are with the pessimists. We may sum up the situation, indeed, by saying that though things at present are not nearly as bad as 'the man in the street supposes, the future outlook, though not necessarily a near future, is probably a good deal worse than he imagines."

So much for the general statement of the issues which hang on this tremendous problem. The whole matter is forced on public attention just now by the conflict in California between Americans and Japanese. The international standing of Japan among the nations seemed to have been established by sacrifices and achievements as heroic, whether in peace or war, as ever were credited to any country," says the "Telepraph." "She took her place as a Great Power, a nation among her equals. Yet in California her subjects admitted under treaty are misused as though they were helots or pariahs. The United States Government acknowledges that injustice has been committed, but is almost absolutely prevented, by the limitations of the American Constitution, from giving effectual redress. That is the deadlock which has been created, and the situation is as difficult for statesmanship at Washington as it is trying to the Government of Tokyo and exasperating to the national sentiment of its subjects.

"A solution can only be reached by placing a very loose interpretation upon the letter of the law, and allowing unconventional and uncompromising common sense to form a substitute for pedantry and parchment. The American case, and we shall endeavour to put it as fairly as the Japanese, is much better in reason than in logie. Whether from the social or the political point of view, the problem for the United States is real and it is grave. It is raised by the procedure of the Californian authorities, whether municipal bodies or State legislature. At their instigation, or through their supineness, the subjects of a great and friendly Power, in peaceful exercise of their treaty rights, have been harassed and humiliated. There has been an endeavour to exclude them from American soil and to boycott them where they are settled upon it. They have been ejected from the public schools and obstructed in the pursuit of their business. There has been an attempt to place a stigma of racial inferiority upon them." | With such issues pending, the President has decided to dispatch the fleet to the Pacific and he has taken this grave step because he is convinced that the risk of aggravating the situation was better incurred than when the remotest danger of leaving the Californian coast defenceless, in case some unfortunate incident should precipitate a crisis.

div.head: The Mixed Tribunals.
div.p: The Council of Ministers has signed a decree authorizing the grant of a credit of L E. 13,000 to the Mixed Tribunals for increased expenditure

div.head: Walls Partial Collapse.
div.p: The wall of a bakery in the Labban quarter has partially collapsed, but happily no one was injured by the fall of débris.

div.head: Saft Khalid Incident.
div.p: The omdeh of Saft Khalid, where occurred the stoning incident, which we reported the other day, in which Prince Kamel Eddin Pasha received a blow from a stone, has been dismissed.

div.head: Motor Car Accident
div.p: A motor car, belonging to Messrs Loukaitis, knocked down a young nativegirl, named Nafisa, while she was crossing a street in the Maarouf quarter on Tuesday last. She received very serious injuries and some twenty days medical treatment will probably be required.

div.head: Fire at Assouan.
div.p: Yesterday morning a fire broke out at Assouan, which caused enormous damage. It began in a Greek bakkal's shop and then made its way to the market where upwards of thirty shops were burnt. Damage to the extent of many thousands of pounds was done.

div.head: To Deal with Brigandage,
div.p: We understand that the Ministry of the interior is forming a small Camel Corps of police in the Assiont Mudirieh for service on the East bank of the Nile. This step has been rendered necessary by the frequency of cases of brigandage, and cattle and camel raiding in that neighbourhood. Mr. T. Russell, the energetic Inspector of the Ministry, is organising the corps.

div.head: Water Supply
div.p: The Mex fountain water supply was stopped the day before yesterday by the fountain being broken during a quarrel among a party of women. A correspondent writes to emphasise the benefits of this free water supply and express the hope that the company will realise the necessity of immediately repairing the fountain and restoring the supply of water.

div.head: Public Health Department.
div.p: On the recommendation of the Director General of the Public Health Department, the Ministry of the Interior has approved of the following appointments :- Bember Eff. Sayed as acconcheor to the Lunatic Asylum, Nached eft. Hanna as veterinary surgeon to the department, Mr. G. McCall as inspector of cattle plague and Ismail Eff. Rouchdi as 2nd class inspector of public health.

div.head: European Chļldren Maltreated.
div.p: An inhabitant of Mex informs us that the day before yesterday five European children living at Mex, while on errands for their parents, were attacked by a gang of native street boys with whips and stones, and that the sum of ten piastres was stolen from one of them. Two young girls managed to run away from the young hooligans, but the other three children all received wounds of more or less dangerous nature. Two of the native boys were arrested and taken to the caracol, where the usual procès-verbal was drawn up.

div.head: Fire in Alexandria,
div.p: A fire broke out in Alexandria yesterday evening about 8 o'clock in a draper's shop of a small street of the Mohamed Ali midan, and was only extinguished after more than a couple of hour's hard work by the fire brigade. The interior of the shop and its contents were completely destroyed, but the walls were left standing and the adjacent shops on either side were only slightly charred in places. Judging from the reports which we have received and from a visit to the scene of the fire the brigade must have worked with great efficiency to have saved the shops on either side, and confined 'the fire to the interior of the one building. It is said that the damages amount to £12,000, and that the insurance only covers £8,000. The shop was well stored with Manchester goods, the whole stock of which is destroyed, but we would not be surprised to learn that their estimation at £12,000 is somewhat exaggerated.

div.head: The Cairo Pollice.
div.p: So much has been said and written about the incompetency of our Cairo police in the local papers, that it is quite a pleasure to be able to report a really smart capture recently effected by the greatly maligned arm of the law. Rizk Awad, a keeper of a "tarboucherie" in Sharia Clot bey, lodged a complaint with the police at the end of last week, to the effect that Bank notes worth L.E. 600, which he had been carrying about in one of his pockets for some days, had disappeared, but he was unable to give any definite information as to when or where he first became aware of the notes being missing. He stated that he was of opinion that he had been robbed, although he could not point out any particular suspect. On the other hand, it was possible that he had simply lost them somewhere in the street. With very little hope or chance of success the police took the matter in hand. Yesterday an agent of police, named Amer Mahanni, while on duty observed a native approach a European and offer three notes of L. E. 100 each for sale, "and his suspicion being aroused, he took the native into custody, with the unexpected result that the whole of the missing som was recovered. The matter is not yet settled, however, as a discussion has arisen in regard to the payment of 10% of the value of the lost property which the owner refuses to make, and therefore, for the present, the money has been confiscated.

London, Thursday.Housni Bey has been interviewed in Paris and has said that the nationalist movement has been taken in an exaggerated phase."It is absurd," he said "to criticise everything the English do, because the English men and England have rendered much service to my country, which they cannot now abandon to us. I fully recognise that the Egyptians must be protected by some nation and it is proper that England should have a moral,financial and military control over the country."

On Tuesday afternoon the session of St. Andrew's Schools was brought to a close by an exhibition of work, and distribution of prizes, in the Boy's High School under the patronage of C. A. Greig Esq. H. B. M's Acting Consul.Prior to the distribution of prizes a varied programme consisting of recitations and dialogues in English, French and Arabic was given in a large tent erected for the occasion-and large though it was it proved insufficient to contain the great assemblage of people, many of whom were unable to obtain seats.This vast gathering bore ample-testimony to the popularity of the school, and an examination of the work on exhibition in one of the large class rooms of the school furnished the secret of this deserved popularity. This work comprised commercial book keeping in French among part of and English, geography and maps, samples of essays and arithmetic in English, and sheets of Arabic writing and translation : but without doubt the best pieces of work in the exhibition were two large wall maps of Palestine, illustrating Old and New Testament times, which were drawn to perfection by Apostolos Constantinides.The recitations and elocution were most creditable and showed that in all three th Department, the languages taught, the pupils receive a thorough training, - the only failing being that on account of the performance being in the open and before such a vast assembly of people, the performers, in order to be heard had to speak rather loudly, and their bests could not be expected.

The second part of the programme consisted of an operatta entitled "Abou Hassan" or " The Baker's Dream," it was first occasion upon which such a thing has been attempted, the performance was exceedingly good. The boys sang tunefully and acted creditably, Master H. Taylor making an excellent "Baker" whilst the "Caliph" was in the capable hands with Master Batey. The other principals were also very good. The whole of the music, staging and scenery were directed by Mr. O. Stanley Heaton who deserves great credit and praise for his hard work and untiring energy in this branch of the work.

The prizes were distributed by Mr. C.A. Greig, the principal prize winners being C. Mazarakis the dux of the school, and the two "Allan" Medallists, M. Oelbaum from the High School, and D. Abramovitch of the Lower School. These medals-one for each school-are presented annually by Major Allan,Glasgow, for Bible study, and the proficiency in this subject could be gauged by an excellent essay on "The Life and Character of Samson," written and exhibited by the medallist Oelbaum.

After the distribution of the prizes Mr. C.A.said that from what was seen of work inside and heard by all, they might rest assured that boys from St. Andrew's School received a very thorough education and need not fear to go and take their places in any department as quite the equals of boys from any other school, and that if any fault could be found it might be the danger to the staff and pupils of working too hard. He congratulated Mr. Buchanan and his staff upon a very successful year's work and concluded by wishing all a very pleasant holiday. After three cheers to Mr. Greig and a like compliment to Mr. Buchanan the proceedings closed with"God Save the King."
It was fitting that a new St. Andrew's flag with the School's initials, presented by Mrs Shorter should be floating over the school for the first time.

div.head:
SUDAN AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS.
TRADE WITH ADEN.
div.p: Aden, July 18.The Sudan is likely to find in Aden a suitable future outlet for its grains and seeds. For the first time a large quantity of gingelly seeds has now been brought by the Egyptian steamer "Missir", and a further quantity is on its way to Aden. The gingelly seeds now imported were sold at Rs 84 per candy, a very suitable price considering the price of the seeds the Sudan. Hitherto all gingelly seeds have been imported from India and Zanzibar, but owing to the rise in price attention has now been turned to the Sudan.

div.head:
ROYAL MESSAGE SUBMITTED
ROBERTSON WILL NOT OPPOSE

div.p: London, Thursday. A gracions message from the King has been presented to both Houses of Parliament recommending that as a signal mark of his Majesty's favour a grant of £50,000 should be made to Lord Cromer in recognition of his eminent services in Egypt.
The Premier stated that the grant-would be discussed next Tuesday.
The "Tribune" states that Mr. Robertson will not oppose the grant.

div.head:
LORD CROMER'S MEMORIAL
MR. R.J. MOSS'S CIRCULAR.
div.p: The Nationalist Press is still making merry over the facts mentioned in the letter of Mr. Robert J. Moss, which appeared in our issue of the 8th inst. Mr. Moss therein stated that over one thousand circulars were issued by post or by hand addressed in accordance with the latest completed list obtainable from the British Consulate at Alexandria. Each circular contained a request that the recipient should give his opinion as to the form the testimonial to Lord Cromer should take, as it would be of assistance if the views of the British Colony could be ascertained before the matter was again brought before the general public. Of these one thousand circulars, 130 were returned through the dead letter office. Therefore of the thousand 870 were received by the members of the British Colony at Alexandria. As only 29 replies were sent back to Mr. Moss, no less than 841 of the persons, who received the circulars, were so indifferent to the question of a testimonial to Lord Cromer that they never took the trouble to answer. As Mr. Moss said, "Until more public interest has been taken in the matter it appears to me to be useless to publish any details." These facts are seized upon with avidity by the Nationalist newspapers and it is attempted to infer from the statements contained in Mr. R. J. Moss's letter that therefore the British Colony "hated the Cromerian Administration." The "Egyptian Standard" thus concludes an article on this subject:-
"Only a few Imperialists adoring it (i e. Lord Cromer's administration) 29 all told."

"And, in order to enable the British nation to bow down and worship these Imperialist financiers, capitalists and stockbrokers, it has to vote a grant of £50,000 to the man whose administration was unis versally 'hated."

It is needless to point out that this deduction from Mr. Moss's words is nonsense. Because only 29 members of the British Colony at Alexandria, out of 870 who receive a circular, took the trouble to reply, it is obvious that to infer that therefore those who failed to reply, hated his Lordship's administration, is quite beside the facts of the case. The real explanation for this indifference is that to most persons here Lord Cromer was only a name. Whenever he was obliged to come to Alexandria to see the Khedive, he used to hurry back to Cairo by the afternoon express. He never made prolonged visits to this city, for which he appeared to have no great affection. Furthermore, it is not surprising it the circular met with such small response, for in such a lethargic and indifferent atmosphere it is impossible to evoke enthusiasm about anything. We do not doubt, however, that when the memorial is finally decided upon, and the various factions claiming preference satisfied, the appeal for subscriptions will be as heartily answered by the British colony of Alexandria as by any.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Ibrahim Pasha Fouad is due back from Europe Text Wednesday.
Kaimakam Connolly Bey, A.A.G., Recruiting, has assumed Command of the Cairo District vice Miralai Herbert Bey, Acting Officer Commanding, proceeded on leave.

Dr. Ruffer, President of the Quarantine Board, is leaving Alexandria on the 15th prox. for Switzerland. In September he will go to Berlin in order to open an important decision at the International Congress on Hygiene Afterwards he will proceed to Rome, where he will represent Egypt at a non-Inter national Sanitary Conference at Rome. The discussion which the President of the Quarantine Board will open at Berlin will deal with the sanitary measures to be taken in harbours.

Father Bernard, director of the Harran Hospital for Lepers, is arriving in Egypt shortly from Rome en route for Abyssinia where he will hand Menelik an autograph | letter and the Grand Cross of the Order o St. Sepulchre on behalf of the Pope. To Queer Taïtou he will present a splendid mosaio re presenting the Byzantine Madona.

Mr. Biagiotti chief clerk of the Mixed Tribunal of First Instance in Cairo, has asked permission to retire on the termination of his leave. This news will cause considerable regret in the Court where Mr. Biagiotti is universally esteemed.

div.head:
THE VIVANTE AFFAIR.
AN ERRONEOUS REPORT.
div.p: A serious mistake has been made by the "Egyptian Standard" in reporting the Vivante affair. Our contemporary says:

"Writing on July 22nd our Alexandria correspondent adds a further item to the growing literature on the Vivante affair. People are apparently astonished at the news that Vivante on entering the hotel was accompanied by a lady friend who is well known in Alexandria as a person of high reputation, and who happened to stop in the same hotel. She remained it seems some time in Vivante's room, and there information ceases.
"The accounts of this fact contain agly insinuations. Does it follow that because this lady was the last person known to speak with Vivante before the crime she is accordingly the author of it
"We must await events, simply recording for the present that the lady enjoys an excellent and honorable reputation, is well connected, and is above suspicion."

Those who have followed our accounts of the affair will recognise that the paragraph is absolutely unwarranted and must be categorically denied. There have never been the slightest grounds for asserting that Vivante was accompanied by a lady, and we can only regret that such an untrue statement should have been made.

From enquiries made at the Greek Consulate we learn that the effects of Vivante which were examined there consisted merely of a few pieces of linen and some commercial letters, none of which afforded the slightest clue or had any bearing on the crime. Meanwhile the hands of the Greek Consular authorities are tied, and, though doing their best to assist the police, they can give no material aid until the latter have established the identăty of the assassin, when, in the event of his proving to be a Greek subject, they will conduct the case.
In the meanwhile we might repeat that it has been definitely concluded that Vivante was murdered and that the idea of suicide cannot for one moment be entertained.
Dr. Ralli, physician to the Greek Hospital, has given it as his opinion that the murder was committed by one man by means of the coup du Pore François, as theorised by us in a recent issue.

div.head:
ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
THE ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICE.
div.p: Sedky Bey, the General Secretary of the Alexandria Municipality, has compiled a report on the working of the administrative service during the past year, from which we extract the following facts.

During the legal year, 1905-1906 judgment was given in thirty cases in which the Municipality was a party. Twenty three of these cases were decided in favour of the Municipality. The amount paid for expropriating property was L.E. 10,500. The encashments for sales of land and tanzim surpluses came to about L.E. 20,000.
There were 2,258 cases for the illegal occupation of the public ways. Out of this total there were only a hundred acquittals. There were 27 actions against chemists and 175 seizures of dogs.
The Tanzim drew up 115 misdemeanour cases and 806 unhealthy establishments were proceeded against

The way in which the footpaths in Alex-andria are unwarrantably occupied as though they belonged to the shopkeepers is a public nuisance of considerable magnitude. Sedky Bey remarks on this subject :-

Une réforme qui a été obtenue grâce aux de marches pressantes de la Municipalité, est celle de l'exécution en matière d'occupation indue de la voie publique. Précédemment, l'exécution d'un jugement ordonnant la cessation de l'état de contravention n'était qu'un simulacre ; le contrevenant ne tardait pas à occuper à nouveau la voie publique, et il fallait de nouvelles poursuites pour le contraindre à déguerpir, et ainsi de suite. Cette situation devenait intolérable et le respect même attaché aux jugements en était compromis. Le Ministère de la Justice, après examen de la question, a prescrit l'inntilité des poursuites nouvelles, lorsqu'on premier juge ment était intervenu et a autorisé la Police employer, an besoin, la force publique pour débarrasser la voie publique des occupations abusives. Les bienfaits de cette mesure commencent à se faire sentir, et ils seraient certainement plus évidents si la Police pou vait prêter son concours d'une façon plus constante.

No less than 308 proces-verbaux were drawn up against natives for non-vaccination. Not a single European, however, was proceeded against, because as Europeans are not obliged to register births it is therefore impossible to discover if their children are regularly vaccinated. This is a very unfortunate state of affairs and the ravages which small-pox has recently made among the European population of Alexandria may be considered as a set-off against the privileges of the Capitulations.

The correspondence of the Municipality has increased enormously of late years. Last year 4,730 European and 20,782 vernacular letters were received and 5,777 European and 17,600 vernacular letters despatched.
Last year the Municipal regular employee included 291 officials, 18 engineers, 18 doctors and 22 apprentices.

div.head:
EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT.
THE CENSUS.
div.p: Mr. John Robertson asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether the recent Egyptian census has been found to be imperfectly taken ; whether, in consequence, it is proposed to take a fresh census ; and, if so, when.
Sir E. Grey.--I understand that the final figures of the recent census have not yet been issued.
Mr. Robertson asked further whether the right hon. gentleman could state if it were the fact, as stated in the pro-Government Press of Egypt, that the census is grossly defective.
Sir E. Grey.-My information is simply that the final figures are not yet published.
THE LAMBERT AFFAIR.

Dr. Rutherford asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he is aware that M. Lambert, a Frenchman, resigned the directorship of the Khedivial School of Law through differences with Mr. Dunlop, the Secretary General of the Ministry of Public Instruction, Egypt; whether he will explain the reason for the appointment of an Englishman to a Government post invariably held, since the establishment of the School of Law, by subjects of the French Republic, in view of the spirit of Article V. of the Anglo-French Declaration of 1904 ; and whether Mr. Dunlop will be requested to resign.

Sir E. Grey.--I understand that Mr. Lam. bert, whose resignation was not desired, resigned his post as Principal of the Khedivial School of Law in consequence of a misunderstanding with the Ministry of Public Instruction on the subject of his leave. In view of the growing demand t) enter the English side of the School the Egyptian Government decided to promote one of the existing English Professors to the vacanoy thus created ; there is no ground for the suggestion that such an appointment is in any way contrary to the spirit of the Anglo-French Agreement of 1904 and no reason whatever tor the reflection upon Mr. Dunlop contained in the question.
Mr. Robertson asked whether it is the fact that Mr. Hill in his new post will have to give legal instruction in French and whether his qualifications for giving such instruction are very imperfect.

Sir E. Grey answered that the authorities had fully taken into account the qualifications of the gentlemen available for the position, and were fully satisfied that the best possible choice had been made.

The "Temps" in its evening's issne of the 18th inst. refers to Sir Edward Grey's declaration in the House of Commons respecting the Lambert case, and declares that he avoids the real issue, which is that the Anglo-Rgyptian Administration has persistently run counter to the friendly guarantee of French educational interests which was stipulated for in 1904. The French organ asserts that a roundabout policy of repression and discouragement towards the Khedivial School of Law and French instruction generally has always formed part of the programme of Lord Cromer and his subordinates. It proceeds to give a list of the cases where it alleges that young Englishmen of insufficient experience have been promoted to various posts, where French candidates who possessed better claims and qualifications had been passed over.

While allowing the French schools every nominal liberty, in conformity with the 1904 Agreement, the Cromer policy has made plain to the parents of children attending them that their only chance of a career under Government service lies in future through the British Schools.

The "Temps" observes: "The teaching of French in Egypt is not merely a moral force to which we hold, but it is also an instrument of economic force which we cannot renounce. 1 If French loses ground we shall see our commercial statistics dwindle with the number of those who read our books, newspapers, catalogues, and prospectuses. And our commerce is worth defending. To resume our engagement of 1904 is limited to the abandonment of all anti-British political action in Egypt. That engagement we have kept, and shall keep scrupulously; but on economic grounds and on intellectual grounds we have agreed to no renunciation, and shall consent to none."

div.head:
THE YEMEN REBELLION.
FURTHER REBEL SUCCESSES.

div.p: Sana is still holding out, but Nadhiea district is reported again invested by the rebels, and severe fighting is reported, but no details have been received

Is is reported that the rebels have occupied Asesudda, a fertile valley with many village about three miles from Nadhiea, through which lies the route from Kataba to Sana. Large numbers of the rebels are scattered over the route from Nadhiea to Sana, and are occupying several eminences.
The inhabitants of Kataba are reported to have removed most of their moveable property to Dthala and other places, as an attack on Kataba by the rebels is apprehended by them

div.head:
AN EGYPTIAN FIND.
SAYINGS OF CHRIST.
div.p: The latest of the many discoveries by archeologists in Egypt occurred some months ago at Edfou, in Upper Egypt, near the site of an old Coptio monastery. A native, clearing his ground of stones, accidentally laid bare a stall tomblike receptacle.
In this he found a number of parchment M88., bound in thick papyrus covers. He sold them to an Arab dealer for a few pounds, and the Arab in turn 'sold them to a Copt for £500.

The news had by this time gone abroad, and the representatives of the foreign museums made energetic efforts to acquire the M88. The good fortune of securing them fell to Mr. de Rustafjaell, F.R.G.S., the well-known tavol ler and explorer, and he sent them to England, since when a great foreign university has tried to obtain them.

The MSS. had already been identified as a unique Coptic and Greek ecclesiastical M88. of the ninth to the eleventh centuries, of great archeological importance, and about a dozen rolls of sixth-century papyri. Among them are twenty-five leaves of apocryphal sayings of Christ, in a Coptic translation of a lost Grook original, of which previously only thirteen leaves were known, twelve in the National Gallery at Paris, and one at Berlin.

The discovery also comprised parts of the Gospels of St. Matthew, Bt. Mark and St. Luke in Greek and Coptic, the Apocalypse of St. John, in Coptic ; the history of the Miracles by Cosmos and Damien (dated sixth century); a sermon by St. Pisenthios in Coptio (this copy is unique) ; a sermon by St. Cyril, (A.D. 851-886) on the Sacred Cross, in Coptio, from an existing Greek original (this is the only complete edition), and a unique MS. in the Nabian language dealing with the life of St. Menos and the canons of the Nicacean council.

div.head: A UNIQUE LANGUAGE
div.p: Only fragments of MSS. in the Nubian language have been discovered hitherto. There are very few scholars in the language and scarcely any published literature. Hence the present volume, which is in an excellent state of preservation, is of first rate importance.

From a dedication in one of the M88. the monastery on the site of which they were discovered, is proved to have been named " St. Mercury of the Mount at Edfo," and one of the volumes is a history of the Martyrdoh of St. Mercurios.
A modern Coptic monastery stands near e the site, but the name of the older foundation had been entirely lost until this discoyery.

Egypt has also yielded another " find to Mr. de Rustafjaell's researobes. In the Desert of the Nile he found, among the remains the Paleolithic flint factories, a number crude and weather beaten limestone was resembling troughs and pots like ironstone concretions. He holds them to be of Palæolithic age. They are certainly older the the Neolithic age, which covered a considerable period in Egypt before the advent of the First Dynasty in B.C. 4440.

Mr. de Rustafjaell thinks it is difficult to over-estimate the importance of this discovery in connection with the history of civilisation in general and the evolution of pottery in particular. Some of the vessels have already been promised to the British Museum.

Mr. de Rastafjaell, in an interview, told a." Daily Mail" representative that the M88.,which he had secured, were undoubtedly of very great interest. The unique Nubian MS. h is a little bound volume, about 6ins. by 4ins.It contains a history, or life of St. Menos, fone of the early Christian martyrs.

There was only one person in England who t could read Nubian-an official in the British Museum-but there were many who could . I make out a good deal of it as the basis of the of language was Greek. He had had considerable experience in Egyptian explorations, which he had followed up as a hobby. He had also ext|plored at Cyzicus in Asia Minor, but all his discoveries there he had been obliged to leave behind him in accordance with the Government regulations. He had had a very tempting offer a for the Nubian volume from Germany, but he felt that it should remain in England.

div.head: FRANCE IN EGYPT.
div.p: According to a calculation recently made by some French banks in Paris the amount of French capital invested in the Suez Canal Company, Egyptian Funds, and the Credit Foncier Egyptien, is three milliards of France.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Le marché des valeurs présente sensiblement le même aspect qu'hier. Bien que les titres égaptions continuent à hausser à Londres, ici la tenne est faible et la cote plutôt en baisse. On n'allégue d'ailleurs aucun motif à cet état de choses agtre que la situation toujours gênée de notre place.

En ce qgi concerne les valeurs dirigeantes, l'Agricole bénéficie de 1/16 à 7 13/16, tandis que la National Bank pard 1/8 4.19 3/16: LA Daire.gegne 1/16.4.13 7/16. Quant à l'Obligation Crédit Foncier, l'ancienne est plus faible à 300.fr, vendeurs, tandis que la nouvelle progresse de 255.à.257.
La Ramleh Héchit de 4 5/8 à 4 1/2, les Privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie de 186 d. 135, les Privilégiées Bière du Caire de 95 à 90, la Banque d'Athènes de 107 1/2 à 107.
Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land tombe de 1 5/16 à 1 1/4, les Estates de 1/2 à 13/32, la Levant de 9/16 à 1/2, et la Leyico de 5/1 6à 1/4.

En hausse, au contraire, la Spinning remonte de 1/4 à 5/16, la Salt and Soda de 16/3 à 17, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 19/6 à 20, l'action nouvelle Comptoir de 2 1/8 à 2 3/16, et l'United de.6/16 à 11/32.
Tout le reste de la cote demeure sans changement. Les transactions ont été clairsemées et peu importantes, comme hier, la tendance générale étant aux ventes et les acheteurs faisant défant.

Le vente aux enchères d'Obligations Crédit Foncier qui aura lieu des jours-ci consiste prin cipalement en obligations anciennes ; c'est ce qui explique lat stationnaire de la valeur. On dit cependant que la vente sera aisément absorbée par les demandes qui se sont produites a l'occasion de la forte baisse de ces jours derniers.

A propos de l'Arditi on parle du mécontentement général des actionnaires dont la plupart seraient d'accord pour ne pas accepter l'arrangement voté récemment par l'assemblée générale des courtiers en valeurs; arrangement spécifiant que les opérations faites sur les actions de la Bourse, and Banking à £1 og au-dessus se liquideront et se règleront sans livraison de titroy par simple différence, en prenant pour base le cours de £1,prix nominal de l'action, et que les opérations au-dessous de £ 1 seront liquidées et compensées au prix ou elles auront été faites et sans livraison de titres. Le Comité informe à ce sujet les Agents que le règlement des actions. Bourse and Banking se fait par le moyen du Clearing et les prie de nouveau de faire parvenir au secrétariat leurs factures acquittées et faites suivant le modèle déposé au dit secrétariat.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication la démolition de sept maisons sises'aux Abassiri, Balactaria et rue el Ghedawi.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 60(soixante).
Le cahier des charges est déposé au Bureau du Secrétariate Technique où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 6 Aout 1907.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour la démolition de diverses maisons (sept)."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 6 Aout 1907 à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 24 juillet 1907.

div.head: THE FINANCIAL CRISIS
NATIVE OPINION.
div.p: The vernacular Press is devoting a considerable amount of space to the various aspects of the financial crisis.
" Al Watan" in an article on the abuses of company promoting in Egypt remarks :-

"The conduct of the Egyptian Government with the various companies controlled by foreign interests has always been faulty and loose. Somehow or other every company of foreign capitalists can do in Egypt what in other countries is regarded next to impossible, either because the Government is too indul. gent or because the laws and circumstances of the country allow of abuse and mismanagement to an intolerable degree. The evil may be due to a combination of causes and circumstances with which the authorities are unable to cope ; the difficulties may be rather in. surmountable in certain cases. But that our Government has for many years neglected to do its duty with these companies goes with ont saying. If ever a Government was over. ruled by foreign companies, that Government is undeniably our own.

"It is impossible for us to go into details about even one tenth of the many companies with which the country has been pestered, and which pursue a course of misrule unchecked and uncontrolled. Take some of the oldest and hest companies for example, of which the Cairo | Water Company is a fine specimen. This com. pany promised to reduce the price of water in Cairo, at least in small houses. The promise was wrung from the managers after repeated representations to the Government by the Legislative Council and years of complaint in the local Press. Yet the reduction has been a farce and the enorinous income of this company rises at the cost of the public from year to year. The same company levies a permanent tax of P.T. 5 a month, as the price of its little "counter" over and above the excessive price of water. The price of this blessed counter never ends, and the company goes on levying its tax ad infinitum owing to the lack of public control.

"The same may be said of the Light Com pany which levies even a higher tribute in the unending manner. So despotic have these companies become that they rule the public while the Government stands aloof interfering only to give further concessions whenever they are applied for. And so dariny have certain clever thieves become that they issue false shares in the name of imaginary companies and publicly sell these shares while the authorities sit inconcerned. We have seen shares of this description of which some persons in Minia Province bought for many hundred pounds, only to discover subsequently that their money was robbed by daring thieves who have not been traced because no attempt has been inade by the authorities in this direction. | It appears that the want of proper supervision and official control is at the root of all trouble connected with these companies. No one in the various public departments is particularly responsible or concerned with the working of companies. Complaints, therefore, are lost in chaos and the abuse of concessions goes on at tull speed. Obviously there is need for a separate department in one of the Ministries to be entrusted with the work of superintending and controlling all these companies in their work. The formation of this bureau or department will at once relieve the public and put a stop to abuses which are without a parallel in other lands. We trust that the Government will consider our suggestion and eradicate an old evil once and for all.

div.head: NATIONALIST IDEAS
div.p: "Al Lewa," which has "Nationalism" on the brain, urges a "National" Cotton Syndicate, That newspaper says:-
"No one can now deny the fact that the Euryptian nation is progressing.

"We accordingly seize the opportunity to ask Egyptian patriots to form a national syndicate for the sale of our cotton and to prevent the stock-brokers from interfering or intermediating between the peasantry and the cotton merchants, and thus secure to the fellaheen the great gains made out of this business by these individuals.

"The syndicate if formed can send a deputation every year to Europe to agree with the financial houses and cotton factories on the question of prices, and to conclude contracts in the name of the syndicate.

"The price lists should then be published every day in the local press during the cotton season so that the fellaheen may be kept informed of them and know the differences between the prices advanced by the brokers and those advanced by the syndicate.

"The syndicate should in our opinion be composed of men like Ismail Bey Dabbus, Abd el Latit Bey el Sufani to represent. Al Bebera Province ; Ahnied Fasha Abu el Futouh and Moustafa Pasha Abu 'el Ezz to represent Gharbieh ; Mahmoud Bey Abd el Ghaffar, Mahmoud Pasha Abu Hussein's and Abd el Megid Bey Sultan to represent Menufieh; Ibrahim Pasha Murad, Saleh Bey el Shawarbi Galiubieh : Moustafa Bey Khalil, Ismail Pasha Abasah, and Amin Pasha el Shamsi Gharbieh Province : Mahmoud Bey el Shennawi Dakahlieh: and the like in other provinces of Upper Egypt. The Dairas and Wakfs Administrations shonld also be represented on the syndicate."
The writer asks el Said Musa el Akkad to invite the members willing to compose a syndicate to a general meeting and to put the necessary plans for the work, before them.
The writer adds that this article contains a summary of his opinion and suggestions regarding this all important subject and that they could be revised and amended, when considered in detail.

le says that an action of this kind will restore financial confidence in the economical stability of Egypt, bear out the declarations made the other day by Boghos Pasha Nubar at Glasgow, raise the cotton prices to a very high level, and produce great advantage through the deficiency of American cotton this year..

div.head: SECOND STAGE OF THE CRISIS
div.p: El Said Hassan Musa Al Akkad has contributed an article to "Al Ahram" on the second stage of the financial crisis, from which we make the following extracts :
The cause of this crisis is the newly created companies and the rush of the maddened speculators to buy their shares.

The sole cure for the situation is to induce the Court of Appeal of the Mixed Tribunals to give a decision to the effect that the recovery of accounts due should be postponed for four months, provided that the debtor is able to give security in real estate, and that no duties should be taken for the mortgaged property unless the length of time given in the contract is more than four months.

Such a decision would speedily induce the financial and commercial institutions to resume work and enable the companies to liquidate "behind the veil" and without the knowledge of the public. The solid establishments would doubtless in such circumstances save their positions and the others would disappear.
Those fond of speculating in stocks and shares should avoid transactions of the kind with any financial company that is not subject to the Egyptian law.
The Government ought to create a surveillance. lance bureau to supervise the companies throughout Egypt so as to save our country from getting entangled for the second time in a ruinous crisis.

div.head: WAKFS RECEIPTS.
div.p: From the beginning of the present year up to the end of June the receipts of the Wakfs Administration from all sources amounted to L.E. 134,8-15 as against L.E. 122,323 received during the corresponding period of last year. The expenses for the same period amounted to L.E. 138,821 as against L.E. 136,052 expended during a similar ter of 1906. A further sum of L E. 31,875 has been paid from the General Reserve fund for the construction and repair of buildings and mosques, and for expenses connected with certain cultivable properties.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
div.p: The demand for Egyptian Cotton on the spot has again been small, quotations however in sympathy with Futures are 3/16 plb. higher. | In futures a fair business has been done, and the following are the closing values :July 10.50 Oct. 10.42 Jan. 10.32 Aug. 10.46 Nov. 10.39 Feb. 10.31 Sep. 10.44 Dec. 10.35 Mar. 10.31

American Futures. The market this week has been quiet with various moderate fluctuations. To-day's closing values are 2@4 points higher than those of last Thursday. There is no particular feature to record, in spite of continued favorable weather the Crop remains 3@ 4 weeks late and the plant is reported to be small, and requiring a continuance of the same favorable condition. There is little doing except professional trading, and "Bulls" and "Bears" appear equally nervous and hesitating. Attention will soon be concentrated upon the next Bureau report, due about the 3rd of August, and which will be awaited with considerable anxiety, the July report having been so much less favorable than the improved private information had encouraged people to except.

The latest quotations are, delivery :July 6.80 Oct./Nov. 6.51 Feb./Mar. 6.46 July/Aug. 6.79 Nov./Dec. 6.48 Mar./Apl. 6.47 Ang./Sep. 6.67 Dec./Jan. 6.47 April/May 6.48 Sept./Oct. 6,57 Jan./Feb. 6.46 May/June 6.49

div.head: Egyptian State Railways."
NOTICE
div.p: The Administration has the honour to inform the public that tenders will be received up to noon at latest on the 1st November next for the supply of two hundred thousand Pine Sleepers required for the year 1908, according to sample to be submitted to the Permanent Way Department of the said Administration, and the conditions of the specification relating to this supply, of which a copy may be obtained at the Central office of the General Stores at Boulae (Cairo) and at the office of the Inspector of Stores, Gabbary (Alexandria) against payment of 100 milliemes.

All persons desiring to take part in this adjudication must first pay into the Treasury of the Administration a sum of L.E. 200 (Two hundred Egyptian pounds) as a provisional deposit. The successful tenderer must increase this sum to the amount of ten per cent of his accepted offer.
Delivery of these Sleepers is to commence 1st June 1908 at earliest, and terminate by 10th September 1908.
Tenders must be accompanied by a stamped paper of 30 milliemes as well as by the receipt for the payment of the provisional deposit above mentioned, the whole to be addressed registered post to :-
"The General Manager,
Egyptian State Railways,
Cairo"
and in double envelopes, the inner bearing the following inscription.
"Tender for the supply of Pine Sleepers."
Any offer received later than the day and hour aforesaid will not be taken into consideration.
The Administration is not bound to accept the lowest or any tender, and reserves to itself the right to divide the contract. Cairo, 18th July 1907.
